INSERT INTO `HLP_AREA` (`AREA_ID`, `SCREEN_ID`, `DESCRIPTION`, `LANGUAGE`, `HTML`, `MD5`, `POPUP_WIDTH`, `POPUP_LENGTH`) VALUES ('dataset','datasets','column','','

Dataset

This column contains the dataset's short name.

','','400','400'), ('tables','datasets','column','','

Tables

This column lists the tables in the dataset. The tables are listed by their short names.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','datasets','pagehelp','','

Datasets

This page lists the latest versions of datasets in any status or datastes matching your search criteria if you reached this page by submitting the dataset search form. The latter is accessible by clicking the Search link in the upper right corner.

The datasets NOT in Recorded or Released status are inaccessible for un-authenticated users!

All users can see at least 3 columns here:

  • Dataset indicating the dataset's full name.
  • Status indicating the dataset's Registration status. The latter is indictaed by icons, the labels of which are dispalyed when placing the mouse over them.
  • Tables listing the dataset's tables by their full names.

If you reached this page by submitting the dataset search form and you chose to search for historic versions too, then you can also see a 4th column:
Version indicating the version identifier of the particular dataset version listed. Note that version identifier 2405 does not mean that this is the 2405th version of the dataset. It is simply the unique identifier of the particular dataset version and it simply happens to be numeric.

If you place the mouse over column header and the latter activates, it means the list is sortable by that column. Click the column header to perform the sorting.

Each dataset and common element definition in Data Dictionary goes through a life-cycle. Its phases are marked by Registration status (aka simply status). The Registration status of a dataset definition is specified by the data definers and can be any one of the following:

  • Released (5 ticks) means the definition is accepted by ETCs and EEA and is released for countries to use for download of technical guidelines and templates. Definitions in this status can be accessed by countries.
  • Qualified (4 ticks) level is for closing discussions between ETCs and EEA. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.
  • Recorded (3 ticks) level is for discussions between ETCs and countries if applicable. Otherwise the definition will skip this status and move directly to the Qualified status. Definitions in Recorded status can be accessed by countries.
  • Candidate (2 ticks) means definitions that are included in the Data Dictionary by the EEA or ETC data managers. This level is for opening discussions between ETCs and EEA. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.
  • Incomplete (1 tick) means either existing definitions under consideration to include them into Data Dictionary or new definitions under development where the Data Dictionary is used as a structuring tool or to test dataflows. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.

For authenticated users the left-most column will contain one of the two:

  • Checkboxes for selecting datasets for deletion (if the user has permission to delete the particular dataset).
  • Red asterisks (*) indicating that the dataset has been checked out by somebody. The EIONET user name of that somebody will be displayed if placing the mouse over the asterisk.

Authenticated users can also see the following buttons on top of the list:

  • Add new leads you to the page where you can add a new dataset.
  • Delete selected deletes the selected datasets and refreshes this page. Note that if you reached this page by submitting the dataset search form and you chose to search for historic versions too, then only the selected dataset version is deleted! Otherwise only the latest version of the dataset is deleted.

Only authenticated users can see the Restore action link in the upper right corner. It leads to the list of dataset versions in the recycle bin. The latter contains the dataset versions that were not completely deleted (when deleting a dataset, DD asks if you want to delete it completely or keep for possibility of restoration). The recycle bin page allows you to restore selected dataset versions and you can find more help there.

','','600','600'), ('pagehelp','tables','pagehelp','','

Tables

This page lists tables from latest versions of datasets in any status or tables matching your search criteria if you reached this page by submitting the table. The latter is accessible by clicking the Search link in the upper right corner.

Tables from datasets NOT in Recorded or Released status are inaccessible for un-authenticated users!

All users can see 4 columns here:

  • Full name indicates the table's full name.
  • Short name indicates the table's short name.
  • Dataset indicates the dataset where the table belongs to. Note that if a dataset name is marked by a red asterisk (*), it means the dataset has been checked out by somebody and the EIONET user name of that somebody is displayed if you point the mouse over the asterisk.
  • Dataset status indicates the Registration status of the dataset where the table belongs to. The different statuses are marked by certain icons. The status names are dispalyed when placing the mouse over those icons.

If you place the mouse over column header and the latter activates, it means the list is sortable by that column. Click the column header to perform the sorting.

As mentioned above, dataset statuses are marked by certain icons and you can see the status name by placing the mouse over the icon. Here's what different status names mean:

  • Released (5 ticks) means the definition is accepted by ETCs and EEA and is released for countries to use for download of technical guidelines and templates. Definitions in this status can be accessed by countries.
  • Qualified (4 ticks) level is for closing discussions between ETCs and EEA. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.
  • Recorded (3 ticks) level is for discussions between ETCs and countries if applicable. Otherwise the definition will skip this status and move directly to the Qualified status. Definitions in Recorded status can be accessed by countries.
  • Candidate (2 ticks) means definitions that are included in the Data Dictionary by the EEA or ETC data managers. This level is for opening discussions between ETCs and EEA. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.
  • Incomplete (1 tick) means either existing definitions under consideration to include them into Data Dictionary or new definitions under development where the Data Dictionary is used as a structuring tool or to test dataflows. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','search_dataset','pagehelp','','

Dataset search page

This page enables you to search for datasets.

More about search criteria is available by clicking the question marks next to them.
You can add more search criteria by using the blue '+' sign at the bottom part of the page. You can remove added criteria by clicking the blue '-' sign that will appear next to them.

The radio buttons below the criteria enable to set the search type. Possible options are:

  • Substring search. This will interepret your inputs as substrings of what you're searching for.
  • Exact search. This will interepret your inputs as the exact phrase you're looking for.
  • Free text search. This will interepret your inputs as free text.

If you have authenticated yourself then you will see the Working copies only checkbox. If this is checked, only working copies are searched for.

Both authenticated and un-authenticated users should see the Include historic versions checkbox. If this is checked, DD returns also all the historic dataset versions matching your search criteria.

Search button speaks for itself. Reset clears your search criteria.

NB! If all the criteria are blank, the query returns the latest versions of all datasets.

If you have authenticated yourself and you have the required permissions, you will also see the Add dataset action link in the upper right corner. This will lead you to the page where you can create a new dataset.

','','400','400'), ('criteria','search_dataset','below the +, no popup','','To find out more about the search criteria provided below, please click on their titles. It is possible to add more criteria by clicking the "+" button underneath. To remove added criteria, use the "-" buttons appearing next to them.','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','search_table','pagehelp','','

Table search page

This page enables you to search for tables.

More about search criteria is available by clicking the information icons next to them.
You can add more search criteria by using the blue '+' sign at the bottom part of the page. You can remove added criteria by clicking the blue '-' sign that will appear next to them.

The radio buttons below the criteria enable to set the search type. Possible options are:

  • Substring search. This will interepret your inputs as substrings of what you're searching for.
  • Exact search. This will interepret your inputs as the exact phrase you're looking for.
  • Free text search. This will interepret your inputs as free text.

If you have authenticated yourself then you will see the Working copies only checkbox. If this is checked, only working copies are searched for.

Search button speaks for itself. Reset clears your search criteria.

NB! If all the criteria are blank, the query returns all tables found in DD.

','','400','400'), ('criteria','search_table','below the +, no popup','','

To find out more about the search criteria provided below, please click on their titles. It is possible to add more criteria by clicking the '+' button underneath. To remove added criteria, use the "-" buttons appearing next to them.

Please use the dataset search page, for searching tables using dataset attributes as search criteria:

','','400','400'), ('GIS','element','gis attribute','','

GIS elements and GIS tables

Some of the tables defined in Data Dictionary might contain GIS (Geographic Information System) data.
In Data Dictionary terms, data elements (i.e. table columns) containing such data are called GIS elements.
Tables containing such elements are called GIS tables.
You can distinguish GIS elements in Data Dictionary by the value of the GIS field in their definitions.
If such a field is missing from the definition's detailed view then it means that the defined data element
is not a GIS element. Otherwise the GIS field can have one of the following values, called the GIS types:

  • [blank]
  • class
  • subclass
  • subtype
You can assign these values in the edit views of data elements.
The moment an element in a table is defined as a GIS element, the moment the table becomes a GIS table
and it's detailed view becomes slightly changed. More precisely, the list of elements is split into two:
one for the so-called normal elements and one for the GIS elements. The 1st one is titled Metadata elements,
the 2nd one is titled simply Elements where the GIS type is reflected in the Type column.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','complex_attrs','pagehelp','','

Complex attributes

This page lists the complex attributes specified of the selected object and
enables either to delete them or open them in edit mode.

While a simple attribute is simply a name/value pair, a complex attribute
is a set of name/value pairs. Every such pair is called a field. For example
address would consist of country, city and street fields. A set of these fields
combines a complex attribute value row. The set of these rows is what is called the
compelx attribute's value.

A complex attribute on this page is given by a table where the table's title in bold
is the attribute's name and the columns represent the attribute's fields.
Every such table is provided with a checkbox and an Edit button in the table's upper
left corner. Use the checkboxes to select attributes for deletion and click 'Remove selected'
to perform the deletion. Use the Edit button to open the attribute in edit mode.
You will find more help once you get there.

NB!
If there are no complex attributes specified yet, the page provides a selectbox
where you can select the attribute you want to specify and the 'Add new' button
for going to specification mode (i.e. edit mode).

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','search_element','pagehelp','','

Data element search page

This page enables you to search for common or non-common elements.

More about search criteria is available by clicking the information icons in their titles.
You can add more search criteria by using the blue '+' sign at the bottom part of the page. You can remove added criteria by clicking the blue '-' sign that will appear next to them.

The radio buttons below the criteria enable to set the search type. Possible options are:

  • Substring search. This will interpret your inputs as substrings of what you're searching for.
  • Exact search. This will interpret your inputs as the exact phrase you're looking for.
  • Free text search. This will interpret your inputs as free text.

There are also radio buttons for specifying if you want to search only for common elements or only for non-common elements. The latter is the default.
If you check 'common elements', the dataset select box becomes disabled, because common elements are not strictly related to one single dataset. If you check 'non-common' elements, the dataset select box is enabled, but the 'Working copies only' checkbox becomes disabled, because there can be no working copies of non-common elements.

If you have authenticated yourself then you will see the Working copies only checkbox. If this is checked, only working copies are searched for.

Both authenticated and un-authenticated users should see the Include historic versions checkbox. If this is checked, DD returns also all the historic element versions matching your search criteria.

Search button speaks for itself. Reset clears your search criteria.

NB! If all the criteria are blank, DD resturns all the latest common element versions or non-common elements from all the latest dataset versions, depending on which radio button you checked.

If you have authenticated yourself and you have the required permissions, you will see the New common element action link in the upper right corner of the page. This will lead you the page where you can start creating a new common element.

','','400','400'), ('shortname','tables','column','','

Short name

This column contains the table's short name.

','','400','400'), ('dataset','tables','column','','

Dataset

This column contains the short name of the dataset this table belongs to.

','','400','400'), ('refurl','dataset','The "Reference URL" attribute','','

Reference URL

This is a stable URL that always refers to the latest version of this definition!

','','400','400'), ('identifier','dataset','The "Identifier" attribute','','

Identifier

Identifier is a unique identifier that is mainly used for internal purposes in the Data Dictionary. It is a character string used to distinguish different elements, tables and datasets within the same context. It's maximum length is 50 characters and it must have no blank spaces. Identifiers are also used as tag names to distinguish elements in XML-formatted data, so their syntax must apply to the same rules as those of XML tags.

NB! A table identifier must be unique within its parent dataset. A data element identifier must be unique within its parent table.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','attributes','pagehelp','','

An attribute in Data Dictionary's context is an attribute of a definition of a dataset, table or data element. Most common attribute of all is 'Name', standing for the name of the defined object. Other attributes could be for example 'Definition', 'Keyword', etc. Every attribute is uniquely identified by its Short name. There are two types of attributes recognized by DD:

  • Simple attribute
    Every such attribute in its instance is a name/value pair. For example 'Name', 'Definition' and 'Keyword' are a good example of simple attributes.
    Note that simple attributes can have pre-fixed sets of allowable values. Often these values are some kind of codes. For example an attribute called 'Datatype' can have values like 'Text', 'Integer' and 'Boolean'.
    Also, a simple attribute in its instance can have multiple values at the same time. For example 'Keyword' could be 'environment', 'water' and 'lake' all at the same time.
  • Complex attribute
    A complex attribute in Data Dictionary's context is almost the same as a simple attribute.
    The difference is that while a simple attribute is a name/value pair, a complex attribute
    is a set of name/value pairs. Every such pair is called a field. For example
    address would consist of country, city and street fields. A set of these fields
    combines a complex attribute value row. The set of these rows is what is called the
    compelx attribute's value.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','history','pagehelp','','

History of a dataset or common element

The Data Dictionary keeps history of datasets and common elements.
The version numbers are called CheckInNo and they are incremented
every time a definition of a dataset or common element is checked in and the user has selected the option for updating the dataset's or element's version (see more in helps of dataset, table and element edit pages).

This page lists the history of the selected dataset or common element.
Please note that for un-authenticated users the history contains only the definitions in Released status.
Every row in this list represents a previous version of the selected
dataset or element. Every version is identified by CheckInNo which is clickable and leads to the version's detailed view. Note that you cannot edit history!

The User column stands for the user who created the version.
The Date represents the date of the creation of the version.

If this is a dataset history and you see a 'D' sign behind the version, it means it has been deleted by you. You can go to 'Restore datasets' page by clicking this sign.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','dataset_tables','pagehelp','','

Dataset tables

This page lists the tables in this dataset.

If you have authenticated yourself and this dataset is your working copy then you will see the following buttons on top of the list:

  • Add new leads you to the page where you can add a new table to this dataset.
  • Remove selected removes the selected tables from this dataset and will refreshes this page. As a result, the removed tables should be gone.

If you see no tables in this list, it means the dataset has no tables.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','table_elements','pagehelp','','

Table elements

This page lists the elements in the given table.

If you have authenticated yourself and this table belongs to your dataset working copy then on top of the page you will see inputs and buttons enabling you to add new elements to this table or remove existing ones.

  • To add a new non-common element enter the new element's alphanumeric identifier into the Identifier box, select the element's Type and click Add or Copy. The element's type can be either either Quantitative or Fixed values. The first one means elements that can have any value within their data type. The second one means elements whose value-set is pre-determined.
    Add creates a new element with the Identifier and Type you selected and it will lead you to the element's edit page where you can enter the rest of the element's attributes.
    Copy too creates a new element with the Identifier and Type you selected, but it will prompt you to select another element from which to copy the rest of the new element's attributes. The prompt will open a view where you can search for the element whose attributes you want to copy. Once you've clicked the desired element in the search results, DD will create a new non-common element where the attributes have been taken from the element you selected to copy, but the Identifier and Type are the ones you entered above. It will then lead you to the edit page of that newly created element where you can edit the rest of the element's definition.
  • To add an existing common element click the Link button. It will open a search page where you can search for the common element you want to add to this table. In the search results, click the desired element and you will be led back to this view where you will see the selected common element among the table's elements.
  • To remove existing elements from this table, select the elements with the help of checkboxes in the left-most column and click Remove selected. As a result, the page is refreshed and the selected elements should be gone. Note that removing a common element does not delete it from the DD. It will simply be removed from this table, but it remains in DD to be used by other tables and datasets.
  • The Save order button saves the order of the elements. You can change the order by clicking on the row of the element you want to move up or down. This will paint the row to blue. Once this is done, use the moving buttons on the table's right. One arrow will move by one position, two arrows will move the selected row to the beginning or the end. Just like CD player. Click Save order to save the changes.



The list of elements is given by 4 columns:

  • Short name is the element's short name.
  • GIS indicates the element's GIS type. If the element is not a GIS element, the value says 'no GIS'. If it's a GIS element, but the GIS type is unknown, the value is simply empty.
  • Datatype indicates the element's data type.
  • Element type indicates the element's data type. It is either Quantitative or Fixed values. See above for what those types mean.

Common elements are marked by C.
If a non-common element has foreign key relations to elements in other tables in this dataset, it is marked by (FK).

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','dataset_model','pagehelp','','

The role of data model is to visually describe the dataset structure (down to the level of elements if needed) in a modeling language. For now, models can be attached to datasets only as simple image files. The DD recognizes three image types- JPG, GIF and PNG. So in order to provide a dataset definition also with its data model, you should first draw the model with your modeling tool and then save it as a file of one of those 3 types.

There can be two models given to a dataset. A simple model should describe the structure only on the tables level, while in the detailed model you can add as many details as you would like. The two models are situated on the model view's separate tabs.

To add a model, click on its tab (simple or detailed) and specify the image file location either on your local file system or in the web. And then press Upload. As a result, the image is downloaded from given location and stored into DD file system.
To remove the added model, click the Remove button.
Note that there can be only one simple model and only one detailed model.
Uploading a model without removing the previous one will overwrite the latter.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','fixed_value','pagehelp','','

Allowable value

This page lists the details of the selected allowable value (aka fixed value). If you're in view mode, those details will not be editable. If you're in edit mode, you find them editable and you can submit your edits by clicking 'Save'. The 'Delete' button will delete this allowable value.
Both Definition and Short description should describe the value's meaning, but Definition should be a bit broader than Short description.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','suggested_value','pagehelp','','

Suggested value

This page lists the details of the selected suggested value.
If you're in view mode, those details will not be editable. If you're in edit mode, you find them editable and you can submit your edits by clicking 'Save'. The 'Delete' button will delete this suggested value.
Both Definition and Short description should describe the value's meaning, but Definition should be a bit broader than Short description.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','suggested_values_edit','pagehelp','','

Suggested values edit page

This page lists the suggested values for this element and provides features to edit them.

An element's suggested values are a set of values that the Data Dictionary suggests to use if the data provider is not sure about which value to provide. These values are by no means mandatory to use. You serve a helping function only. Note that suggested values can only be specified for data elements with quantitative values, i.e. not elements with fixed values.

Every suggested value here in this list is represented by the value itself and the value's definition which helps to understand the value's meaning. Values are clickable and they lead to the value's detailed page.

To add new values, use the new value's input box and Add button. For deletion, use checkboxes to select the desired values and press Delete. The Remove all button speaks for itself.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','suggested_values_view','pagehelp','','

Suggested values

This page lists the suggested values for this element.

An element's suggested values are a set of values that the Data Dictionary suggests to use if the data provider is not sure about which value to provide. These values are by no means mandatory to use. You serve a helping function only. Note that suggested values can only be specified for data elements with quantitative values, i.e. not elements with fixed values.

Every suggested value here in this list is represented first by the value itself and then the value's definition and the value's short description. The latter two help to understand the meaning of the value. Values are clickable and they lead to the value's detailed page.

If the element whose values you are looking at is in edit mode, then you can also see here in this page the 'Edit' button. Use this button to go into mode where you can add/remove new/existing values.

','','400','400'), ('excel','dataset','Help for MS Excel generation','','

Generating MS Excel templates for datasets

MS Excel is one of the most popular formats of data reporting in Reportnet. To help to ease the task of producing them, Data Dictionary enables to generate templates for the MS Excel files to be reported.

In MS Excel format every DD dataset is represented by a workbook, where every sheet represents a dataset table by having the table's short name! Sheets have titled columns where every such column and title represents a data element. The titles are the short names of data elements. For further information about the elements you have to look at the definitions in DD or the PDF you might have generated.

NB! Please note that GIS tables are represented by two separate sheets.
The one for GIS elements is titled tablename and the one for non-GIS elements
is titled tablename-meta.

','','400','400'), ('excel','table','Generation of MS Excel template','','

Generating MS Excel templates for tables

MS Excel is one of the most popular formats of data reporting in Reportnet. To help to ease the task of producing them, Data Dictionary enables to generate templates for the MS Excel files to be reported.

An MS Excel template for a given table is a workbook, where there's only one sheet and it is the sheet representing the table. It has titled columns where every such column and title represents a data element in this table. The titles are the short names of data elements. For further information about the elements you have to look at the definitions in DD or the PDF you might have generated.

NB! Please note that for GIS tables the one sheet is split into two! One for GIS elements, titled tablename and one for non-GIS elements, titled tablename-meta.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','foreign_keys','pagehelp','','

Foreign key relations

Datsets consist of tables and it is only natural that tables can be in foreign key relations with each other. In Data Dictionary foreign key relations are represented by defining a foreign key relation between an elements in one table and an element in another table. The tables have to reside in one and the same dataset.

This page is a list of elements which the selected element is in foreign key relations with. The list is given by 3 columns:

  • Element: the element's short name.
    It is clickable. The click opens the foreign key element's view page.
  • Table: the element's table's short name
  • Cardinality: the type of relationship.
    This can be 0-to-1, 0-to-one-or-more, 1-to-1, etc. Just like in terms of relational databases. See more in the help of the relation's detailed view.
If the elemenet whose foreign keys you are looking at is in edit mode, then you should also see the buttons for adding new relations and deleting existing ones.
To add new relations, click the 'Add' button and this will open a window where you can search for elements in this dataset. When you get the search result list, click the desired element and it will copied to the list of foreign key relations.
To delete existing relations, use the checkboxes in front of rows and the 'Remove' button on top of the table.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','simple_attr_def_view','pagehelp','','

This is a view that lists all the details about this simple attribute. More about what's a simple attribute is available in page help of attributes list.

Short name uniquely identifies the attribute.
Name is a bit more representative.
Since attributes in different contexts can have the same name, Context is used to distinguish them.
Definition is the full definition (i.e. description of its meaning) of the attribute.

Obligation indicates if the attribute's specification in a dataset/table/element definition is mandatory, optional or conditional.
The details following now are only of interest to data definers, not data reporters.

Display type indicates if the attribute is displayed as a text box, text area, select box or an image.
An attribute can have fixed values. If it has any specified, they are listed here. Their details can be found by clicking the 'Fixed values' link.
Display multiple indicates if this attribute can have multiple values at the same time. For example a Keyword could be 'environment', 'water' and 'lake' all at the same time.
Inheritance tells if and how the attribute is inheritable from higher levels (i.e. from dataset level to table level).
Display order indicates the order of attribute display in attributes list and dataset/table/element definitions.
Display for indicates the definitions where this attribute can be used: dataset, table, element with fixed values or element with quanitative values or all together or only some of them.
Finally, if the attribute is to be displayed as a text box, the Display width and Display height indicate the width and height of that text box.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','complex_attr_def_view','pagehelp','','

This is a view that lists all the details about this complex attribute. More about what's a complex attribute is available in page help of attributes list.

Short name uniquely identifies the attribute.
Name is a bit more representative.
Since attributes in different contexts can have the same name, Context is used to distinguish them.
Definition is the full definition (i.e. description of its meaning) of the attribute.

The details following now are only of interest to data definers, not data reporters.

Inheritance tells if and how the attribute is inheritable from higher levels (i.e. from dataset level to table level).
Display order indicates the order of attribute display in attributes list and dataset/table/element definitions.
Fields lists the fields of this attribute. Details of every field can be seen by clicking on their names. To add/remove the fields, use the link at the page bottom.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','complex_attr_view','pagehelp','','

Complex attribute view

This page lists the fields of the complex attribute you selected.
Every column in this list represents a field. Rows represent the field values.

While a simple attribute is simply a name/value pair, a complex attribute
is a set of name/value pairs. Every such pair is called a field. For example
address would consist of country, city and street fields. A set of these fields
combines a complex attribute value row. The set of these rows is what is called the
compelx attribute's value.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','complex_attr_edit','pagehelp','','

Complex attribute edit page

This page lists the fields of the complex attribute you selected and enables you to edit them. Every column in this list represents a field. Rows represent the field values. Editing means you can add new rows and/or remove existing ones.

While a simple attribute is simply a name/value pair, a complex attribute is a set of name/value pairs. Every such pair is called a field. For example address would consist of country, city and street fields. A set of these fields combines a complex attribute value row. The set of these rows is what is called the complex attribute's value.

To add new rows, use the group of field inputs and Add/Copy buttons above the list.
Add simply adds what you typed into inputs. Copy enables you to copy values from all the values existing for this complex attribute in Data Dictionary. You will be provided with the list of these values. To select a desired value, click on its clickable part. To delete existing rows, select them by the checkboxes in front of the rows and click Delete.

NB!
Elements can inherit complex attribute values from the table they belong to, and tables can inherit complex attribute values from the dataset they belong to. This depends on weather the attribute is defined to be inheritable or not (see attribute definition sections).
If a value row is inherited, you won't see the checkbox in front of it!
NB!
There are two types of inheritance. If inheritance is set to be over-writeble, then adding a new row using the inputs above will lose all inherited rows. If inheritance is set to be not over-writable then you can add new rows without losing any inherited rows.

','','400','400'), ('access','dataset','Help for MS Access generation','','

Generating MS Access templates for datasets

MS Access is among the most popular formats of reporting data in Reportnet. To help to ease the task of producing this format, Data Dictionary enables to generate templates for the MS Access files to be reported.

The relation between the generated MS Access templates and datasets in DD is quite straight-forward and logical.

Every generated MS Access template corresponds to a concrete dataset definition in DD. Tables in that template represent the tables in DD. And columns in those MS Access tables represent the data elements in DD.

Tables and columns in generated MS Access files are titled by the identifiers of their counterparts in DD.

The columns in generated MS Access have their data types set according to the data types of their counterparts. Here's the mapping between DD data types and data types in generated MS Access files:

Mapping between DD data types and data types in generated MS Access files
DD data type MS Access data type
string text
boolean boolean
integer int
date text
float float

At the moment the utility DD is using to generate its MS Access outputs does not unfortunately enable to set fixed values for the generated columns!

About each and every column you can find out more specifications by looking at the corresponding data element in DD or its description in generated PDF output.

NB! Please note that GIS tables in DD are represented in MS Access as two separate tables. The one for GIS elements is titled tablename and the one for non-GIS elements is titled tablename_meta.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','import','pagehelp','','

Data import

This page enables to import the data created by DD Import tool.

DD has an MS Access-based helper tool called Import tool.
This tool enables to define datasets, tables and elements (but no attributes!) in a flat table and then afterwards populate the definitions into DD database, using XML as an intermediate format.
The reason for such a tool is simply because when entering a large amount of definitions,
a flat table might be handier than the web-based user interface with its many different views
and clicking back and forth in between them.
More on how to use Import tool is available

The output of Import tool is an XML file. This page enables to import that XML file. Locating the file by using the 'Browse' button or provide the file's URL if it's available on the web. Then press 'Import' button.
The 'Clear' button will clear the inputs.
Import will result in the list of import results which are rather informative.

If you came to this page by clicking 'Import...' on the list of some element's allowable values, there will be a red text notifying that you are about to import allowable values for the selected element. Import tool enables to generate an XML file with allowable values only and this here is the page where you can import them.

Table

This column contains the table's full name.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','elements','General help on this screen','','

Non-common element search results

This page lists the non-common elements matching the search criteria you provided in the data element search page.

The non-common elements from datasets NOT in Recorded or Released status are inaccessible for un-authenticated users!

All users can see at least 5 columns here:

  • Element indicating the element's short name.
  • Type indicating the element's type. It can be one of two: Fixed values or Quantitative. The first means an element where predefined values are the only allowed values. The second means an element that can have any values within the element's data type.
  • Table indicating the table where this non-common element belongs to.
  • Dataset indicating the dataset where this non-common element belongs to. Note that if a dataset name is marked by a red asterisk (*), it means the dataset has been checked out by somebody and the EIONET user name of that somebody is displayed if you point the mouse over the asterisk.
  • Dataset status indicating the Registration status of the dataset where this non-common element belongs to. The different statuses are marked by certain icons. The status names are dispalyed when placing the mouse over those icons.

If you chose to search for historic versions too, then you can also see a 6th column:
Dataset version indicating the version identifier of the particular dataset version where this element belongs to. Note that version identifier 2405 does not mean that this is the 2405th version of the dataset. It is simply the unique identifier of the particular dataset version and it simply happens to be numeric.

If you place the mouse over column header and the latter activates, it means the list is sortable by that column. Click the column header to perform the sorting.

As mentioned above, dataset statuses are marked by certain icons and you can see the status name by placing the mouse over the icon. Here's what different status names mean:

  • Released (5 ticks) means the definition is accepted by ETCs and EEA and is released for countries to use for download of technical guidelines and templates. Definitions in this status can be accessed by countries.
  • Qualified (4 ticks) level is for closing discussions between ETCs and EEA. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.
  • Recorded (3 ticks) level is for discussions between ETCs and countries if applicable. Otherwise the definition will skip this status and move directly to the Qualified status. Definitions in Recorded status can be accessed by countries.
  • Candidate (2 ticks) means definitions that are included in the Data Dictionary by the EEA or ETC data managers. This level is for opening discussions between ETCs and EEA. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.
  • Incomplete (1 tick) means either existing definitions under consideration to include them into Data Dictionary or new definitions under development where the Data Dictionary is used as a structuring tool or to test dataflows. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.

Restore datasets

This page lists the datasets versions that have been non-completely deleted. The latter means that they can be restored. And it is here on this page where you can restore them.

The upper left corner has 2 buttons:

  • Restore selected restores the selected dataset versions.
  • Delete selected deletes the selected dataset versions permanently. They latter means they cannot be restored.

The list has 4 columns:

  • The left-most column contains the checkboxes enabling selection of dataset versions that you want to restore or delete for good.
  • Dataset indicates the name of the dataset version.
  • Version indicates the version identifier of the particular dataset version listed. Note that version identifier 2405 does not mean that this is the 2405th version of the dataset. It is simply the unique identifier of the particular dataset version and it simply happens to be numeric.
  • Tables listing the dataset's tables by their full names.

If you place the mouse over column header and the latter activates, it means the list is sortable by that column. Click the column header to perform the sorting.

Dataset view page

This page provides a view to a dataset definition.

If you have authenticated yourself and you have the required permissions, the upper right corner of the page may contain the following buttons:

  • New version will create a new version of this dataset. You will be instantly led to the view page of that new version where you can start editing it. It will be a working copy until you check it in.
  • Check out will do the same as New version, the only difference is that the working copy will not become a new version when checked in. Instead, it will simply overwrite the current dataset copy.
  • Delete deletes this dataset copy. This does not mean that if you are viewing a Lakes dataset and you press Delete, then all versions of Lakes dataset will be deleted. Only the version you are viewing will be deleted!

Also in the upper right corner you may find these action links:
  • Go to newest leads you the view page of the newest version of this dataset. Seeing this action link indicates that you are viewing an historic version of this dataset.
  • Subscribe will subscribe you to any changes made to any version of this dataset. EIONET's Unified Notification System (UNS) will send you notifications about those changes.

This view page is divided into sections which you can quickly access by using the quicklinks at the top of the page.

Below the quicklinks is a section with links to documents & templates available for this dataset. If you have the right to modify this dataset definition then you can also see the links for uploading new documents and managing the documents' cache. You can find more help when you get there.

The next section lists all the simple attributes of this definition. Every simple attribute is a name/value pair. Some simple attributes can have several values at the same time. Help on every attribute is available by the help icons in their titles.

If the dataset has a data model specified, the simple attributes are followed by a section that displayes the thumbnail of the data model image.

Following the data model is the section that lists the tables in this dataset. Each table is given by its full name and short name, is clickable and the click leads to the table's definition view page.

Following the list of tables is the list of reporting obligations corresponding to this dataset definition in the Reporting Obligations Database (ROD). Each obligation is given by its title, the title of the legal instrument it belongs to and the link to the obligation's details in ROD.

Next is the section listing the complex attributes of this dataset definition. They are complex in that they consist of fields where every field is a simple name/value pair. More detailed view on a complex attribute can be reached by clikcing its title in the left-most column. The center column provides help on every attribute.

At the very bottom of the page is the list of other versions of this dataset definition. Every version is uniquely identified by the dataset number in the left-most column. The list also has indicating the version's Registration status and the date is was released (relevant only when the Registration status is Released). The right-most column of this list provides the link to the view page of that version.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','dataset_edit','pagehelp','','

Dataset edit page

This page enables you to edit the dataset working copy. Your working copy and its changes will not be seen by anybody else until you check it in. This you can do by going back to the view page of this working copy and using the buttons there.

The upper right corner of the page contains the following buttons:

  • Save saves whatever you have entered into the inputs on this page. They will be saved to this working copy. They will not be seen by anybody until the working copy is checked in.
  • Save & close does the same as Save, but it also leads you back to the view page of this working copy. There you will be able to check in whatever you saved.
  • Cancel leads you to the view page of this working copy, without saving anything you entered into the inputs.

Below the above-mentioned buttons, the page is divided into the following sections.

Simple attributes whose values you can edit. Every simple attribute is a name/value pair. Some simple attributes can have several values at the same time. You can define or remove such values by using the +/- icons next to the inputs. + adds a new value, - removes selected values.
Help on every attribute is available by the help icons in their titles.

Following the simple attributes is the section that lists the links to other editable parts of this dataset working copy:

  • Data model leads you to the page where you can provide a visual data model to this dataset.
  • Dataset tables is probably the most important link as it leads you to the page where you can manage the tables in this dataset.
  • Obligations in ROD leads you to the page where you can manage the links that this dataset has to ROD (Reporting Obligations Database).
  • Complex attributes is also quite an important link, because it leads you to the page where you can edit the complex attributes of this dataset. Some of them may be manadatory to specify!

','','600','400'), ('pagehelp','dataset_add','pagehelp','','

Add a dataset

This page enables you to define a new dataset, i.e. add a new dataset definition.

The page lists the definition's simple attributes whose values you can specify. Every simple attribute is a name/value pair. Some simple attributes can have several values at the same time. You can define or remove such values by using the +/- icons next to the inputs. '+' adds a new value, '-' removes selected values.
Help on every attribute is available by clicking their help icons.

The rest of this dataset definition you can edit once you've submitted these simple attributes by clicking Add on top of the page. DD will create the dataset definition and lead you to its edit page.

Table view page

This page provides a view to a table definition.

If you have authenticated yourself and this table is in a dataset working copy and it is your working copy then you can see the following buttons in the upper right corner:

  • Edit leads to the edit page this table.
  • Delete deletes this table from this dataset working copy and redirects you to the view page of the dataset working copy.

This page is divided into sections which you can quickly access by using the quicklinks at the top of the page.

Below the quicklinks is a section that lists the table's simple attributes. Every simple attribute is a name/value pair. Some simple attributes can have several values at the same time. Help on every attribute is available by the help icons in their titles.
The Dataset attribute indicates the dataset this table belongs to. If this is a dataset working copy and it is your working copy, the dataset name is followed by this marker: (Working copy). If it is somebody else's working copy, the dataset name is followed by this marker: (checked out by username). The dataset name is clickable and the click leads to teh dataset's view page.

Following the simple attributes is either a section titled Elements or a section titled Metadata elements or both. They both list the elements in this table. Elements lists NON-GIS elements while as Metadata elements lists GIS elements.
Each element is given by its short name, GIS type (only in the Metadata elements section), data type and element type. The latter can be either Quantitative or Fixed values. The first one means elements that can have any value within their data type. The second one means elements whose value-set is pre-determined. If the element type is Fixed values, you can see those values by clicking the Fixed values link.
Elements in a table can be common elements and non-common elements. The common ones are marked by C.
A non-common element in a table can also have foreign key relations to elements in other tables in this dataset. Such elements are marked by (FK).

The last section is the one listing the table's complex attributes. They are complex in that they consist of fields where every field is a simple name/value pair. More detailed view on a complex attribute can be reached by clikcing its title in the left-most column. The center column provides help on every attribute.

The upper right corner of the page has a Subscribe action link. This will subscribe you to any changes made to this table in its dataset's any version. EIONET's Unified Notification System (UNS) will send you notifications about those changes.

','','600','400'), ('pagehelp','table_add','pagehelp','','

Table add page

This page enables you to create a new table in the given dataset.

The upper right section of the page contains the following buttons:

  • Add creates the new table with the values you entered into the form below. It will lead you to the edit page of that new table where you can edit the rest of the table's definition.
  • Copy enables you to create a new table by copying the basic attributes and non-common elements from another, already existing table. It will open a view where you can search for the table you want to copy. Once you've clicked the desired table in the search results, DD will create a new table where the basic attributes and non-common elements have been taken from the table you selected to copy. It will lead you to the edit page of that newly created table where you can edit the rest of the table's definition.

Please note that both Add and Copy buttons require you to specify the mandatory attributes marked with M.

Inputs on this page represent the table's simple attributes. Every simple attribute is a name/value pair. Some simple attributes can have several values at the same time. You can define or remove such values by using the +/- icons next to the inputs. '+' adds a new value, '-' removes selected values.
Help on every attribute is available by clicking their help icons.
The Dataset attribute indicates the dataset where the new table will belong to. It is clickable and leads to the view page of that dataset.

Once you've entered the data, you are ready to press either Add or Copy.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','element','pagehelp','','

Non-common element view page

Non-common elements belong into a certain single table and they cannot be used in any other tables. They are defined within that certain table and they do not have a life outside of that table.
Common elements do not belong into a certain single table. They can be used in many tables. A perfect example of a common element is for example CountryCode. It is obvious that CountryCode is probably needed in many datasets.

The view page of non-common elements is slightly different from the view page of common ones.

If you have authenticated yourself and this element is in a dataset working copy and it is your working copy then you can see the following buttons in the upper right corner:

  • Edit leads to the edit page this element.
  • Delete deletes this element from this table in this dataset working copy and redirects you to the view page this table.

This page is divided into sections which you can quickly access by using the quicklinks at the top of the page.

Below the quicklinks is a section with links to XML schema and possibly other formats of this element definition.

Next is a section that states the element's type. It can be one of two:

  • DATA ELEMENT WITH FIXED VALUES is an element where predefined values are the only accepted values.
  • DATA ELEMENT WITH QUANTITATIVE VALUES can have any values within the element's data type. DD enables to define suggested values for these elements.

Following the element's type is a section that lists the element's simple attributes. Every simple attribute is a name/value pair. Some simple attributes can have several values at the same time. Help on every attribute is available by the help icons in their titles.
The Table and Dataset attributes indicate the table and dataset the element belongs to. If this is a dataset working copy and it is your working copy, the dataset name is followed by this marker: (Working copy). If it is somebody else's working copy, the dataset name is followed by this marker: (checked out by username).
Both the dataset and table name are clickable and the click leads to their view pages.

Following the simple attributes is a section that lists one of two:

  • Allowable values are a synonym of fixed values and they are listed if the element's type is fixed values.
  • Suggested values are listed if the element's type is quantitative values. They are values suggested to the data supplier if he does not know or is not sure what to enter. The data supplier is not obliged to use them.

If this element has foreign key relations to some other elements in this dataset, the allowable/fixed values section is followed by a section that lists those relations. The 1st column contains the name of the related element (it is clickable and the click leads to the view page of that element). The 2nd column contains the name of the table where the related element resides.

At the very bottom of the page is a section that lists the element's complex attributes. They are complex in that they consist of fields where every field is a simple name/value pair. More detailed view on a complex attribute can be reached by clikcing its title in the left-most column. The center column provides help on every attribute.

This a view that enables to edit all the details about this complex attribute. More about what's a complex attribute is available in page help of attributes list.

Short name uniquely identifies the attribute.
Name is a bit more representative.
Since attributes in different contexts can have the same name, Context is used to distinguish them.
Definition is the full definition (i.e. description of its meaning) of the attribute.

The details following now are only of interest to data definers, not data reporters.

Inheritance tells if and how the attribute is inheritable from higher levels (i.e. from dataset level to table level).
Display order indicates the order of attribute display in attributes list and dataset/table/element definitions.
A complex attribute can be linked to a harvester. The latter harvests the possible values of the attribute fields from outside world. Later in dataset/table/element definitions you can select any of those values and they will be automatically changed whenever they change in the outside world. This outside world would most likely be some kind of LDAP directory. If you don't want to link, choose -- no link --.
Fields lists the fields of this attribute. Details of every field can be seen by clicking on their names. To add/remove the fields, use the link at the page bottom.

To save your changes, click 'Save' at the bottom of the page. To delete the attribute, click 'Delete'.

Allowable values

This page lists the allowable values (aka fixed values) for this element.

An element's allowable values are a set of pre-fixed values which the element can have. It cannot have any other values once these are specified. And they can be specified only if the element is set to be of fixed values type.

Every allowable value here in this list is represented first by the value itself and then the value's definition and the value's short description. The latter two help to understand the meaning of the value. Values are clickable and they lead to the value's detailed page.

If the element whose values you are looking at is in edit mode, then you can also see here in this page the 'Edit' button. Use this button to go into mode where you can add/remove new/existing values.

Allowable values edit page

This page lists the allowable values (aka fixed values) for this element and provides features to edit them.

An element's allowable values are a set of pre-fixed values which the element can have. It cannot have any other values once these are specified. And they can be specified only if the element is set to be of fixed values type.

Every allowable value here in this list is represented by the value itself and the value's definition which helps to understand the value's meaning. Values are clickable and they lead to the value's detailed page.

To add new values, use the new value's input box and Add button. For deletion, use checkboxes to select the desired values and press Delete. The Remove all button speaks for itself.

It is also possible to import new values from an XML-formatted file extracted from Data Dictionary's Import tool. More help will be availabale if you click the Import... button.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','foreign_key_rel','pagehelp','','

This page lists and enabls to edit the details of a foreign key relation.

A foreign key relation in DD's terms is the same as it is in terms of relational databases, because in principal a DD dataset is a database. A foreign key relation exists between two columns of separate tables in the same database. So in DD a foreign key relation exists between two elements of separate tables in the same dataset.
The relation is described by its Description and its Cardinality. The latter indicates if the relation is 0-to-1, 0-to-one-or-more, 1-to-1, etc. Please keep in mind that in Data Dictionary a foreign key relation is direction-less. Nevertheless, the sides of the relation are marked by A and B, just to notify that we're tlaking about sides.

To save changes, click 'Save'. To delete the relation, click 'Delete'.

In select boxes, the cardinaltiy of '+' stands for one or more, cardinaltiy of '*' stands for zero or more

News

The data specifications for the 2004 Eurowaternet data collection are released in the data dictionary.

','','400','400'), ('text','doc1','The documentation text (in the dotted square)','','

Data Dictionary - functions, services and users

The Data Dictionary is used to support the delivery of environmental data by countries to Reportnet. The contents in the data dictionary are used to generate pdfs of the technical specifications for dataflows as well as Excel templates. The Data Dictionary also introduces the possibility of simple automated validation of deliveries by countries and facilitates the development of data submission interfaces.

Data Dictionary holds definitions of datasets, tables and data elements. Each of these three levels is defined by a set of attributes, the core set of which corresponds to ISO 11179 standard for describing data elements. The whole attribute set is flexible and attributes can be added / removed from/to the system.

The Data Dictionary provides:

  • countries with detailed specifications of what to produce and report, on a website as well as in pdf documents for download;
  • data reporters with Excel templates to facilitate reporting;
  • definitions of parameters as input for technical quality control and automated validation of the reported data;
  • those using data reported by countries with a single point of reference for obtaining information about the specifications;
  • a platform for harmonisation discussions and processes;
  • a simple means to reuse existing specifications when reporting obligations are revised or new ones are defined.

Reporting obligations are usually long-lasting. The definitions found in the Data Dictionary, therefore, are relatively stable, but are updated prior to a new dataflow collection.

The users of the Data Dictionary are data reporters and data definers as well as dataflow administrators.

','','400','400'), ('text','doc2','The documentation text (in the dotted square)','','

Concepts & terms - datasets, tables, data elements

Datasets

In Reportnet and DD's context a dataset is a collection of tables containing the reported data. Often the "tables" will actually recede to a single table only. In a way DD datasets are stand-alone databases. Usually they come as MS Access databases or MS Excel files. They are subject to certain data flows and obliged to be reported by Reportnet players according to legislation. In many cases a dataset corresponds to a dataflow. For example there is the CDDA dataset defined in DD, which contains the information about reported data within that same-named data flow

Tables

A table in DD's context is a table in dataset. Columns in a table stand for data elements, rows stand for their values.

Data elements

A data element in Data Dictionary's context is a column in a table. The figure above provides a visual representation of what a table and its elements (columns) are.
On the highest level there are two classes of data elements in DD:

  • non-common elements belong into a certain single table and they cannot be used in any other tables. They are defined within that certain table and they do not have a life outside of that table.
  • common elements do not belong into a certain single table. They can be used in many tables, i.e. they can be part of many tables. You could also call them harmonised elements. They are potential candidates to be used in many datasets and tables and thus have been harmonised to avoid repetitions. A perfect example of a common element is for example CountryCode. It is obvious that CountryCode is probably needed in all datasets and many tables.

Data elements could be for example StationCode, StationType, Longitude, etc. And while Longitude can be measured and StationCode could be anything, StationType would probably have values from a pre-fixed set. These differences represent the 2 distinct data element types that DD recognizes:

  • Element with fixed values (aka allowable values or code lists)
    An element where predefined values are the only accepted values. In ISO 11179 terms referred as "characteristic 1" or "characteristic of type 1".
  • Element with quantitative values (aka measured values)
    An element that can have any values within the element's data type. In ISO 11179 terms referred as "characteristic 2" or "characteristic of type 2". DD enables to define suggested values for these elements.

Attributes

Datasets, tables and elements in DD are defined by a set of attributes, the core set of which corresponds to ISO 11179 standard for describing data elements. The rest of the attributes are usually specific to Reportnet business rules and in any case the attribute set is flexible- an administrator can dynamically add/remove attributes to/from the system. Most common attribute of all is 'Name', standing for the name of the defined object. Other attributes could be for example 'Definition', 'Version', etc. There are two types of attributes recognized by DD:

  • Simple attribute
    Every such attribute in its instance is a name/value pair. They represent the same concept of attribute as in ISO 11179 part 3. For example the mentioned 'Name', 'Definition' and 'Version' are a good examples of simple attributes. NB! Note that simple attributes can have pre-fixed sets of allowable values, just like the elements. Often these values are some kind of codes.
  • Complex attribute
    A complex attribute in DD's context is almost the same as a simple attribute. The difference is that while a simple attribute is a name/value pair, a complex attribute is a set of name/value pairs. Every such pair is called a field. For example address would consist of country, city and street fields. A set of these fields combines a complex attribute value row. The set of these rows is what is called the complex attribute's value.
Important simple attributes when defining a data element are:
  • Datatype
    Indicates if the element's values are strings, integers, booleans, etc. Also specifies if decimals are to be used, and how many decimals are accepted.
  • MaxSize/MinSize
    The max/min length of a data element value in terms of digits or characters. For example if an element's MaxSize is 4, its value 'hello' is one char too long. Or if an element's MinSize is 5, its value '146' is one digit too short.
  • MaxValue/MinValue
    Can be applied only to data elements of numeric Datatype and limits the element's numeric value. i.e. value '9.55' is too much if MaxValue is '9'.
Important complex attributes when defining a dataset, table or element are:
  • SubmitOrganisation
    The organisation that has added or changed the data element definition. This is mandatory to specify for all dataset, table and element definitions!
  • RegistrationAuthority
    Institution authorised to register the data definitions.

You can learn more about each and every attribute through using the DD, because each and every attribute in the DD user pages is provided with online help about its meaning and point.

','','400','400'), ('text','doc3','The documentation text (in the dotted square)','','

Data Dictionary - administrative tools - login mode

Adding or revising the content

Revision and definitions of new datasets is handled by persons who have obtained administration rights and have logged in by pressing the Login button.

  • Revision of data definitions: Once you log in, you will be provided with additional functions on the left-hand pane, enabling you to add new data definitions or revise content. This you can do manually, by writing into the forms on the web pages.
  • You can import data definitions directly in XML format. EEA has developed an MSAccess database for preparation of the data definitions, which you can then generate into XML format which in turn can then be imported into Data Dictionary database.
  • Each data definition can be represented in XML Schema format and you can see (and save) them when pressing the relevant link in the upper part of definition views.

Adding or revising the definition structure

Each dataset, table and data element is defined by a set of attributes. A lot of them correspond to ISO 11179 standard for describing data elements. Data Dictionary attribute set will be relatively stable. However, the system is flexible and an administrator can dynamically add/remove attributes from/to the system. To search for attributes, administrator can use the Attributes button on the left-hand pane.

','','400','400'), ('public_outputs','dataset','The "Public outputs" attribute','','

Public outputs

Public outputs are these automatically generated outputs (in the documents & templates section at the top of definition pages) that should be availabale on this dataset definition for un-authenticated (i.e. non-logged-in) users.
This attribute enables to control which exactly should they be. At the moment only two outputs are supported in this function- the PDF output and the MS Excel output. Whatever you set here on the dataset level, is also applied on its lower levels. This means that if you don't allow to show the MS Excel template for this dataset, it is also not allowed for its tables.
This attribute is displayed only for users who have the right to edit this dataset!
In view mode it is disabled.

CheckInNo

The Data Dictionary keeps history of datasets and common elements.
The version numbers are called CheckInNo and they are incremented every time a definition of a dataset or common element is checked in and the user has selected the option for updating the dataset's or element's version (see more in helps of dataset, table and element edit pages).

','','400','400'), ('short_name','dataset','The "Short name" attribute','','

Short name

A short name is a character string used to operationally identify content components within the Data Dictionary. ie how users and data definers commonly refer to a table or an element or a dataset. A short name is not used as a unique identifier in Data Dictionary. For example, several tables in a dataset can have the same short name. A short name can contain any characters, including white space.

','','400','400'), ('regstatus','dataset','The "Registration status" attribute','','

Registration status

Each dataset and common element definition in Data Dictionary goes through a life-cycle. Its phases are marked by Registration status (aka simply status). The Registration status of a dataset or common element definition is specified by the data definers and can be any one of the following:

Released (5 ticks)

The definition is accepted by ETCs and EEA and is released for countries to use for download of technical guidelines and templates.
Definitions in this status can be accessed by countries.

Qualified (4 ticks)

This level is for closing discussions between ETCs and EEA.
Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.

Recorded (3 ticks)

This level is for discussions between ETCs and countries if applicable. Otherwise the definition will skip this status and move directly to the Qualified status.
Definitions in Recorded status can be accessed by countries.

Candidate (2 ticks)

Definitions that are included in the Data Dictionary by the EEA or ETC data managers. This level is for opening discussions between ETCs and EEA.
Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.

Incomplete (1 tick)

This can be existing definitions under consideration to be included in the Data Dictionary or new definitions under development where the Data Dictionary is used as a structuring tool or to test dataflows.
Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.

  • Element with quantitative values (aka measured values)
    An element that can have any values within the element's data type. In ISO 11179 terms referred as "characteristic 2" or "characteristic of type 2". DD enables to define suggested values for these elements.

','','400','400'), ('dataset_number','dataset','The dataset number','','

Dataset number

Data Dictionary enables to create different versions of logically the same dataset. For example there can be different versions of the Lakes dataset. Every such version is stored as a separate dataset copy in the DD database and is uniquely identifed by the Dataset number.

If you see a Lakes dataset whose dataset number is 2405, it does mean that this the 2405th version of the Lakes dataset. It simply means that the unique id number of that dataset copy in DD is 2405. 2406 might already be assigned to a copy of Groundawater dataset and 2407 might again be assigned to a new version of Lakes dataset. So the number basically indicates the sequence in which the dataset copies in DD are created. The bigger the number, the newer the dataset is.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','dataset_working_copy','','','

Dataset working copy view page

This page provides view to dataset working copy.

When you check out a dataset or create new version of it, DD creates a new copy of that dataset and that will be your working copy. This is the copy where you do your changes and once you're done, you check it in. The check-in makes your changes visible to others. If you checked in with the Registration status of Released or Recorded, your changes will become visible to everybody, including un-authenticated users. If the Registration status was anything else, your changes will be visible to authenticated users only.

The upper right corner of the page contains the following buttons:

  • Edit will open the dataset's edit form.
  • Check in will check in all edits that you did.
  • Undo checkout cancels the checkout and deletes the working copy.

The Subscribe action also available in the upper right corner will subscribe you to any changes made to any version of this dataset. EIONET's Unified Notification System (UNS) will send you notifications about those changes.

This view page is divided into sections which you can quickly access by using the quicklinks at the top of the page.

Below the quicklinks is a section with links to documents & templates available for this dataset. If you have the right to modify this dataset definition then you can also see the links for uploading new documents and managing the documents' cache. You can find more help when you get there.

The next section lists all the simple attributes of this definition. Every simple attribute is a name/value pair. Some simple attributes can have several values at the same time. Help on every attribute is available by the help icons in their titles.

If the dataset has a data model specified, the simple attributes are followed by a section that displayes the thumbnail of the data model image.

Following the data model is the section that lists the tables in this dataset. Each table is given by its full name and short name, is clickable and the click leads to the table's definition view page.

Following the list of tables is the list of reporting obligations corresponding to this dataset definition in the Reporting Obligations Database (ROD). Each obligation is given by its title, the title of the legal instrument it belongs to and the link to the obligation's details in ROD.

Next is the section listing the complex attributes of this dataset definition. They are complex in that they consist of fields where every field is a simple name/value pair. More detailed view on a complex attribute can be reached by clikcing its title in the left-most column. The center column provides help on every attribute.

At the very bottom of the page is the list of other versions of this dataset definition. Every version is uniquely identified by the dataset number in the left-most column. The list also indicates the version's Registration status and the date is was released (relevant only when the Registration status is Released). The right-most column of this list provides the link to the view page of that version.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','common_element','pagehelp','','

Common element view page

Common elements do not belong into a certain single table. They can be used in many tables. A perfect example of a common element is for example CountryCode. It is obvious that CountryCode is probably needed in many datasets.
Non-common elements belong into a certain single table and they cannot be used in any other tables. They are defined within that certain table and they do not have a life outside of that table.

The view page of common elements is slightly different from the view page of non-common ones.

If you have authenticated yourself and you have the required permissions, the upper right corner of the page may contain the following buttons:

  • New version will create a new version of this element. You will be instantly led to the view page of that new version where you can start editing it. It will be a working copy until you check it in.
  • Check out will do the same as New version, the only difference is that the working copy will not become a new version when checked in. Instead, it will simply overwrite the current element copy.
  • Delete deletes this element copy. This does not mean that if you are viewing a CountryCode common element and you press Delete, then all versions of CountryCode commone element will be deleted. Only the version you are viewing will be deleted!

Also in the upper right corner you may find these action links:
  • Go to newest leads you the view page of the newest version of this element. Seeing this action link indicates that you are viewing an historic version of this element.
  • Subscribe will subscribe you to any changes made to any version of this element. EIONET's Unified Notification System (UNS) will send you notifications about those changes.

This page is divided into sections which you can quickly access by using the quicklinks at the top of the page.

Below the quicklinks is a section with links to XML schema and possibly other formats of this element definition.

Next is a section that states the element's type. It can be one of two:

  • DATA ELEMENT WITH FIXED VALUES is an element where predefined values are the only accepted values.
  • DATA ELEMENT WITH QUANTITATIVE VALUES can have any values within the element's data type. DD enables to define suggested values for these elements.

Following the element's type is a section that lists the element's simple attributes. Every simple attribute is a name/value pair. Some simple attributes can have several values at the same time. Help on every attribute is available by the help icons in their titles.

Following the simple attributes is a section that lists one of two:

  • Allowable values are a synonym of fixed values and they are listed if the element's type is fixed values.
  • Suggested values are listed if the element's type is quantitative values. They are values suggested to the data supplier if he does not know or is not sure what to enter. The data supplier is not obliged to use them.

If this common element is used in any tables, then the next section lists tables using this element. Every table is given with its name (clickable and the click leads to its vew page), dataset name (also clickable and leads to the dataset's view page) and the table's owner given by user name.

Next is the section listing the element's complex attributes. They are complex in that they consist of fields where every field is a simple name/value pair. More detailed view on a complex attribute can be reached by clikcing its title in the left-most column. The center column provides help on every attribute.

At the very bottom of the page is the list of other versions of this common element. Every version is uniquely identified by the element number in the left-most column. The list also indicates the version's Registration status and the date it was released (relevant only when the Registration status is Released). The right-most column of this list provides the link to the view page of that version.
