','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','common_element_add','pagehelp','','

Common element add page

This page enables you to create a new common element.

The upper right section of the page contains the following buttons:

  • Add creates the new common element with the values you entered into the form below. It will lead you to the edit page of that new element where you can edit the rest of the element's definition.
  • Copy enables you to create a new common element by copying the basic attributes from another, already existing common element. It will open a view where you can search for the element you want to copy. Once you've clicked the desired element in the search results, DD will create a new common element where the basic attributes have been taken from the element you selected to copy. It will lead you the edit page of that newly created element where you can edit the rest of the element's definition.

Please note that both Add and Copy buttons require you to specify the mandatory attributes marked with M.


The first thing you must do on this page is to select the new element's Type.
If you selected the element's type to be quantitative values, the second thing you must do is to select the element's Datatype.
This is emphasized because both selections reload the page with empty inputs, so you will lose anything you entered prior to performing any of these two selections.

The element's type can be one of two:

  • DATA ELEMENT WITH FIXED VALUES is an element where predefined values are the only accepted values.
  • DATA ELEMENT WITH QUANTITATIVE VALUES can have any values within the element's data type. DD enables to define suggested values for these elements.

Once you've done the above mentioned selections, you can enter data into the rest of inputs which represent the element's simple attributes. Every simple attribute is a name/value pair. Some simple attributes can have several values at the same time. You can define or remove such values by using the +/- icons next to the inputs. '+' adds a new value, '-' removes selected values.
Help on every attribute is available by clicking their help icons.

Once you've entered the data, you are ready to press either Add or Copy.

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','common_element_edit','pagehelp','','

Common element edit page

This page enables you to edit the common element working copy. Your working copy and its changes will not be seen by anybody else until you check it in. This you can do by going back to the view page of this working copy and using the buttons there.

The upper right section of the page contains the following buttons:

  • Save saves whatever you have entered into the inputs on this page. They will be saved to this working copy. They will not be seen by anybody until the working copy is checked in.
  • Save & close does the same as Save, but it also leads you back to the view page of this working copy. There you will be able to check in whatever you saved.
  • Cancel leads you to the view page of this working copy, without saving anything you entered into the inputs.

Below the above-mentioned buttons, the page is divided into the following sections.

Element type, which can be one of two:

  • DATA ELEMENT WITH FIXED VALUES is an element where predefined values are the only accepted values.
  • DATA ELEMENT WITH QUANTITATIVE VALUES can have any values within the element's data type. DD enables to define suggested values for these elements.

The next section lists the simple attributes whose values you can edit. Every simple attribute is a name/value pair. Some simple attributes can have several values at the same time. You can define or remove such values by using the +/- icons next to the inputs. + adds a new value, - removes selected values.
Help on every attribute is available by the help icons in their titles.

Following the simple attributes is the section that lists the links to other editable parts of this common element working copy:

  • Allowable values is a synonym for fixed values and this link is displayed only if the element's type is FIXED VALUES. It leads you to the page where you can manage this element's allowable/fixed values.
  • Suggested values link is displayed only if the element's type is QUANTITATIVE VALUES. They are values suggested to the data supplier if he does not know or is not sure what to enter. The link leads you to the page where you can manage this element's suggested values.
  • Complex attributes is quite an important link, because it leads you to the page where you can edit the complex attributes of this element. Some of them may be manadatory to specify!

','','400','400'), ('pagehelp','common_element_search_results','pagehelp','','

Common element search results

This page lists the common elements matching the search criteria you provided in the data element search page.

Common elements NOT in Recorded or Released status are inaccessible for un-authenticated users!

All users can see at least 3 columns here:

  • Element indicating the element's short name.
  • Type indicating the element's type. It can be one of two: Fixed values or Quantitative. The first means an element where predefined values are the only allowed values. The second means an element that can have any values within the element's data type.
  • Status indicating the element's Registration status. The different statuses are marked by certain icons. The status names are dispalyed when placing the mouse over those icons.

If you chose to search for historic versions too, then you can also see a 4th column:
Version indicating the version identifier of the particular element version. Note that version identifier 2405 does not mean that this is the 2405th version of the element. It is simply the unique identifier of the particular element version and it simply happens to be numeric.

If you place the mouse over column header and the latter activates, it means the list is sortable by that column. Click the column header to perform the sorting.

As mentioned above, statuses are marked by certain icons and you can see the status name by placing the mouse over the icon. Here's what different status names mean:

  • Released (5 ticks) means the definition is accepted by ETCs and EEA and is released for countries to use for download of technical guidelines and templates. Definitions in this status can be accessed by countries.
  • Qualified (4 ticks) level is for closing discussions between ETCs and EEA. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.
  • Recorded (3 ticks) level is for discussions between ETCs and countries if applicable. Otherwise the definition will skip this status and move directly to the Qualified status. Definitions in Recorded status can be accessed by countries.
  • Candidate (2 ticks) means definitions that are included in the Data Dictionary by the EEA or ETC data managers. This level is for opening discussions between ETCs and EEA. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.
  • Incomplete (1 tick) means either existing definitions under consideration to include them into Data Dictionary or new definitions under development where the Data Dictionary is used as a structuring tool or to test dataflows. Definitions in this status cannot be accessed by countries.
